growing.water: Low to moderate; drought-tolerant once established
growing.soil: Adaptable; prefers fertile, well-drained soil but grows in poor, compacted soils too

planting.spacing: Let grow naturally or thin to 6-12 inches if cultivating
planting.whenToPlant: Any time (self-seeds readily); sow in spring if intentionally growing
planting.propagation: Primarily by seed; roots can also regenerate new plants
planting.depth: Surface sow or barely cover seeds (~1/8 inch)

careAndMaintenance.pruning: No pruning needed; deadhead if controlling spread

harvestingAndUsage.whenToHarvest: Leaves: early spring (young leaves less bitter); Flowers: when fully open; Roots: fall for medicinal use
harvestingAndUsage.howToHarvest: Pick leaves by hand or with scissors; pull flowers; dig roots carefully
harvestingAndUsage.preservation: Leaves and flowers: dry or freeze; Roots: dry for tea or tinctures
harvestingAndUsage.edibleOrToxic: Entire plant edible; safe when harvested from clean areas (avoid contaminated soils or sprayed lawns)
harvestingAndUsage.culinary: Young leaves in salads or saut√©ed; flowers for fritters, wine, or syrup; roasted roots as coffee substitute

medicinal.Liver & Gallbladder Support: Roots traditionally used as a detoxifying tonic; supports bile production and liver health.
medicinal.Digestive Aid: Bitters in leaves and roots stimulate appetite and digestion.
medicinal.Diuretic: Known as a natural diuretic (the name 'pissenlit' in French means 'wet the bed').
medicinal.Anti-inflammatory & Antioxidant: Modern studies show potential anti-inflammatory and antioxidant properties.

harvestingAndUsage.aromatic: Mild earthy aroma; not typically used for fragrance

ecologicalInfo.wildlifeResistance: Not typically browsed; deer may nibble foliage in absence of other food

funFacts: Every part of the dandelion is edible and useful.
Deep taproots help break up compacted soil and bring nutrients up to the surface.
Dandelions are one of the first food sources for bees in spring.
